MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR

1ST APRIL, 1990 TO 31ST MARCH, 1991



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [8th Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head J (cont.) -

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head J be reduced by $10 in respect of Code JD 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, I have three cuts under this amendment. Can I take them one after the other?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Dr S. Vasoo: Sir, we should pay close attention to the problems of destitute families. This is because there are large numbers of children in these families who have potentials that we can develop. I feel that some close attention could be given so that the potentials of these children could be enhanced in order that some of these families can break out from the poverty cycle.

    Sir, any provisions directed to help these families will be in the long term interest to try and reduce the problems faced by destitute families. The social health of the community is reflected by our capacity to care and though it is necessary that these families should help themselves many of them are unable to help themselves unless help is rendered.

    Sir, it is estimated that there are 39,000 households in chronic hardship. They consist mainly of widows, single parents, and families suffering from chronic sickness. The per capita income of these families is less than $125 a month. It is indeed difficult for these families to try and meet the minimum household needs. All these households have young children who are our nation's resources. The children of these households have potentials to be developed provided we can organise various social assistance schemes to assist them. In this respect, I am pleased that the Government is intending to implement the dollar-for-dollar contribution to help voluntary organisations to develop programmes to assist these families. I hope that all grassroots organisations that intend to undertake this programme will be considered and supported.

    Sir, as we make further economic progress, the standard and cost of living will increase and these destitute families will likely lag behind. Life will be increasingly difficult for destitute families, especially Government services, such as health, education and public utilities are restructured and privatised. If no concrete help is extend to this group, particularly their children, they will unlikely be able to break out from their poverty trap.

    There is, therefore, a case for some support measures to help these families.

Column: 733

These families should not be assisted through welfare handouts which will lead to long-term dependency. The measures should consist of programmes to upgrade the skills of the families and to improve the educational achievements of the children. In this respect, I would like to ask the Minister what plans are being made by the Ministry to assist destitute families more specifically.

    Sir, turning to the development of community-based programmes for the aged. I note that about 8.3% of our population consists of the aged who are 60 years and above. In absolute numbers, there are about 230,000 aged persons and most of them are living in our older public housing estates. Whilst most families are able to provide care and support for the aged, there is a growing number of families requiring assistance to meet the needs of the aged sick and the problem is likely to become more acute because of the increasing number of old people who are likely to be subjected to various physical and other health related problems.

    Sir, the need is therefore quite urgent and we should try and see what we can do to try and provide supportive services for the aged sick. Therefore, as I see it, there is a need for setting up more community service programmes, such as home-help, day-care and rehabilitation for this group of aged sick. Most voluntary and community organisations could be encouraged to establish these services. However, they find it difficult to do so without grants from Government to meet the operational costs. In view that the demand for community-based programmes for the aged will become more urgent in the near future, I would like to ask the Minister what steps are being taken by the Ministry to encourage and develop more community-based programmes to help families that may likely face problems in caring for the aged.

    Sir, on the area of grants for child-care services, I take note that there is an increasing number of latchkey children that are known to be left alone unsupervised in some of the lower income house-

Column: 734

holds. Most of our child-care services cater for children below the age of six years. However, there is a growing demand for care and supervision of children between 6 and 11 years old. Working mothers, particularly those who work in factories, will find before and after school care programmes most helpful.

    Sir, are there plans by the Ministry to encourage the development of such a service and what assistance will be extended to organisations to start such a service to cope with the problems of latchkey children.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, upholding the family as the basic block of society is supposed to be one of the PAP's core values. The Government should therefore do its utmost to help destitute families, defined by the Report of the Advisory Council on Family and Community Life as "those families who for various reasons face hardship in meeting the minimum household requirements for daily living". And the Report states that "currently about 22,140 families have an earned income below the minimum household expenditure". Assuming, Sir, that each family consists of four persons, then the number of those in the destitute families would come to 88,560, a very sizeable number and proportion of our population.

    If the Statistics Department should review the minimum household expenditure in line with the present high cost of living and inflation, the actual number would surely be much, much higher. Those who are destitute, unlike our Ministers who are drawing fat salaries, live miserable lives.

    Facts show that poverty is a real problem in the midst of plenty in Singapore. It cannot be easily wished away or covered up. PAP grassroots members have spoken of it recently in the PAP Convention and PAP Members have spoken of it in the House right here. Of course, Ministers, because of lack of good arguments to counter what has been pointed out, frequently repeat unflattering, disparaging remarks about Dr Lee, that I think in terms of the 1960s instead of the 1990s, that Dr Lee is a Rip van Winkle and that I must get

Column: 735

out of my cocoon. It would appear, Sir, that from the very facts that I have just related -just only a little bit of it - it is the Ministers themselves, not Dr Lee, who should get out of the cocoon and wake up to the reality that is in our midst.

    Yes, Sir, poverty exists, and it is a pity that some of our Ministers may not have gone to visit the small little cubicles in which their constituents live. If the Minister for Finance is here, I would advise him to go along to Smith Street and Trengganu Street and see how these people live in small little cubicles. The fact that many of our Ministers take the opportunity to gain some political propaganda by giving ang pows during festive seasons should also testify to the fact that there is poverty in Singapore.

    In 1987, 368 people over 60 years old, a quarter of all suicides, took their own lives because they could not afford or had no one to take care of them in their old age or illness. I ask, Sir, what concrete steps has Government taken to help alleviate the hardships of such destitute families? Will the Government consider giving adequate financial aid to those who are in real need, as already disclosed in the Report of the Advisory Council?

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Sir, I would like to commend the Minister for setting up the Advisory Council on Family and the Aged to strengthen the family and develop a cohesive and caring community. We all know this objective is easily said than done.

    In this highly commercialised and materialised society, there is a concern as to how we can preserve basic core values within the family and to uphold the family as the basic building block of society. As a famous Confucian teaching goes: (    ). This is a teaching of how to strengthen the family and develop a caring community. The first step is to train ourselves to the fullest. The second step is to create a happy family before coming to the third step of running a state effectively and finally, the last step, of contributing to the good of mankind.

    We do not only need theoretical teachings but also practical examples. I am glad that various ministries are currently

Column: 736

promoting family life education. For instance, the Ministry of Education through its moral education and good citizen programmes is teaching our school children the right values and behaviour. The Ministry of Health is organising talks on marriage and parent education programmes for young couples and parents. And the Ministry of Community Development is carrying out its public education programmes on family life. All these efforts are good. However, in order to avoid duplication and wastage of resources, I think we should have closer coordination among the various Ministries to pool resources together. I am supportive of offering fiscal incentives to encourage young couples to have more children and to have them early. This will help to solve some of our population problems.

    The point now is how to encourage young couples to have a right attitude towards marriage. I think besides theoretical teachings, parents, teachers, national leaders and prominent figures could set the social norm and be role models for the younger generation. In this respect, I would like to suggest the MCD or civic organisations consider giving national awards for model families, model couples, model children, etc. We already have the Mother of the Year Award. Why not also a Father of the Year Award? Our fathers need just as much encouragement to be good and responsible fathers.

    Now, I would like to touch on the supporting services promoted by MCD in strengthening the family.

Setting up of family service centres

    The First Deputy Prime Minister has recently announced the setting up of family service centres to provide greater family support service at the community level. Here I would like to bring to the Minister's attention a few factors for consideration.

    The charges of the family service centres should be affordable. I am glad that the Minister has announced yesterday that the Government will give capital grant and operational subsidy to family service centres. I agree that we should not become

Column: 737

a welfare state, but we should help the destitute to help themselves. The family service centre could implement more preventive and developmental activities for low-income families.

    The Ministry should also set up guidelines to monitor the quality of the service offered by family service centres and ensure that at the initial stage, the family service centres should be spread out into major housing estates, and there should not be more than one centre in one estate. In drawing up the guidelines, the Ministry should also take into consideration the problem of increasing divorce rate. Today, the number of divorces has increased by 22%, from 1,643 cases in 1985 to 2,004 in 1989. The dilemma between materialistic gains and responsibilities in setting up a family is related to the problem of balancing career development with marriage, parenthood and family piety. Hence I would like to urge the Minister to provide services to help women suffering from stress, abuse, physical violence and marital breakdowns, etc, to learn to cope with the family and social changes.

    The Ministry should also assist in the training of staff offering counselling at family service centres. I understand that although NUS trains several social work students every year, most of them do not end up working in social service organisations. At present, some of the voluntary and welfare organisations are facing problems in recruiting qualified social workers. Furthermore, I understand that welfare volunteers only comprise 2% of our population in Singapore. This is quite low when we compare to 12% in UK and 30% in the USA. Therefore, I would like to urge the Ministry to help the welfare and voluntary organisations offering training to train more volunteers and staff in the field of welfare services.

    The other family support service I would like to touch on is the before and after school care service for school-going children. At present, some of the schools and voluntary organisations are offering the after and before school care to school children. I think there is a need for the

Column: 738

Ministry to give some guidance and assistance to these operators. We should encourage more community centres and schools to provide such services.

    The last area I am going to touch on is child care services. I must thank the Ministry of Community Development for their support in child care development in Singapore. However, two areas still need a lot of attention. One area is the need for trained personnel. With the Institute of Education and NTUC providing training to child care teachers, we are still in need of developing the teaching staff and trainers in the institutes of higher learning, eg, diploma, degree or post-degree training in early childhood education and child psychology. At the moment, no such courses are available in Singapore. I would like to suggest that the Ministry assist the training institutions by offering scholarships to the teaching staff to upgrade themselves through courses overseas.

    Lastly, the number of workplace child care centres is still very small. I would therefore like to ask the Minister whether there is any plan to encourage employers to set up more workplace child care centres.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, the Ministry of Community Development has done an excellent job, assisting and encouraging individuals, organisations and employers to set up child care centres for the benefit of working mothers. It is indeed a good sign that more and more child care centres are being set up in private residential estates, at the void decks of HDB flats as well as at companies' premises. The easy availability of these child care centres has encouraged more and more women to enter or re-enter the labour market and help to contribute to the economy of Singapore. At the same time, they help to ease the labour shortage to a certain extent. With more child care centres being set up, I would suggest that the Ministry take a short pause and take stock of the existing numerous child care centres to ascertain whether or not the supervisory role of these centres is adequate and satisfactory.

    Sir, it is easy to ensure a suitable site for a child care centre with proper layout,

Column: 739

furnishing, equipment and other essential physical facilities. But it is entirely a different cup of tea, for example, if the centres were to provide and maintain a high standard of child caring and child raising skills. The quality of this fast-expanding service must not be compromised. As we all know, Singaporean parents normally want the best for their children. A few days ago, we read in the newspapers that parents even make use of their domestic maids to queue up overnight outside a kindergarten centre just to get places for their children.

    Sir, many of the child care supervisors, teachers and assistants are young women. Some are not married and some have not even become mothers. As such, they may not have the necessary experience and expertise to provide the essential care for the young children. There is no need for these women to possess high academic qualifications. Even 'O' level qualification is not necessary. One of the important factors is that these young women must have the motherly love for children so that they will understand the needs of young children. They must also look upon these young children as if they are mother to them, full of patience, understanding, care and concern and, of course, love.

    Sir, I am no expert in this field, but as a parent of two young schooling children, I at least know the basics of proper upbringing of children. Hence, I want to find out from the Minister what sort of assistance in the form of child care training has been provided to the supervisors, teachers and assistants of child care centres.

    Sir, training for these personnel is very important. Parents place their young children in the child care centres with trust and confidence and expectation that their children will be in safe hands of well-trained and responsible child care givers, so that they can concentrate on their day's work at their workplaces without distractions and much worry.

    Next, I would like to find out from the Minister what other measures are being taken by the Ministry to ensure that adequate and proper supervision of child care centres are carried out. I have the following questions for the Minister. Is the Minis-

Column: 740

try ensuring that the educational programmes for child care centres are suitable for the various age groups of children? Are the dietary recommendations made by the family development branch for infants and older children strictly followed at child care centres?

    Finally, Sir, may I also ask the Minister whether or not the recommended number of staff to child ratio as required for each age group of children is maintained? There should not be overcrowding just because there is a high demand by working mothers for places for their children in child care centres.

    Sir, the Ministry of Community Development has a capable Minister who knows best what child bearing, child caring and child upbringing are all about. Therefore, I would expect a more satisfactory response to my queries.

     The Chairman: Dr Ho.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I have an cut under this amendment.

     The Chairman: It is Dr Ho's turn. You can wait for your turn.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Toa Payoh GRC): Thank you, Sir. I support the views put forward by Dr Vasoo on the plans to assist destitute families. Currently, the Ministry of Community Development has a very stringent means test to qualify applicants for public assistance. When applicants for public assistance are found to be able to get help from relatives and friends, they are disqualified from public assistance. There is an estimate of about 22,140 very low income families belonging to the category which is living slightly above destitute standards. But when these families are faced with some severe setbacks such as the loss of the wage earner, they are likely to fall into destitution if left without support. Very often, these families have arrears in rental and PUB bills. When they cannot pay the HDB rentals, HDB will evict them. When they cannot pay PUB bills, PUB cuts off the water and electricity supply. And if the family has school-going children, the children cannot even study at home because there is no light.

Column: 741



    I would like to propose a scheme to help these families. Will the MCD consider a rent and utilities assistance scheme to help these destitute families to meet the basic needs for shelter and utilities? This could be just temporary assistance until one of the wage earners gets a job. But very often, the wage earners of these families tend to have no skills and hence have difficulties in getting a job. So arrangements could be made to send them for on-the-job training or skills training and the Skills Development Fund could be approached to provide full funding for the skills training.

    Children belonging to such families also need support. I would like to suggest MCD consider a scheme where they liaise with the Ministry of Education and hence the schools to ensure that these children get a decent breakfast or decent lunch while in school. This can come through a subsidy given directly to the school to administer, to provide for the children and this subsidy could include things like bus fares, school uniform, textbooks and stationery.

    Sir, another group of people who need some form of special public assistance is the single parent families. Not only do they need financial support, they may also need counselling and psychological assistance. Some of these single parent families also have young children to look after. To allow single parents to work, I would like to suggest to the MCD to provide some form of public assistance which could cover the cost of child care service.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam)( In Mandarin): Sir, in 1986, people who received public assistance came to about 3,874. Since then, the number of such recipients has been declining. This year, the projected number of public assistance recipients is only 3,380, compared to 3,390 last year. The difference is very negligible. This is a good sign. On the other hand, it also means that there are people who are in difficulty and need public assistance from the State.

    Last year, during the debate on the budget for MCD, in reply to my query the

Column: 742

Minister said that public assistance rates would be reviewed in 1990. I hope the Minister will have some good news for this House and the recipients of public assistance. I would like to urge the Minister to review the public assistance rates according to the present standard and cost of living so that the recipients will be able to meet their daily expenses until the next review of the public assistance rates.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, the sum spent on public assistance has been greatly reduced through the years. In 1988, because of the elections, public assistance was increased - for one person, from $90 to $120; two persons, $140 to $185; three persons, $180 to $240; and for four persons, $220 to $295. Only those who qualify under the strict means test criteria, like the aged destitute, disabled, mentally ill, chronic sick, widows and deserted wives with children under 12 years old, according to the Minister, will be able to receive public assistance. Government knows that these small sums of public assistance are not adequate. The Council of Social Services had already reported in 1980, 10 years ago, that the minimum requirements for a family of four would be about $450 a month. Now, allowing for inflation and higher cost of living, the sum should be anything between $600 and $700 at least. Today, Ministers have given themselves big increases in salaries. Do they also think of those who are less fortunate, and especially those who are in need of public assistance?

    The stringent conditions imposed for granting public assistance should also be relaxed. I think it is time that the public assistance plus the stringent conditions for it be all reviewed. Even if the public assistance should be doubled, the total amount to be spent on such aid is still very small. But that would certainly go a long way to help those unfortunate people. Would the Minister give serious consideration to this matter this time?

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Marine Parade GRC): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for Community Development to consider providing more administrative, advisory as well as other support services to community run homes for the aged and their senior citizens' recreation centre.

Column: 743



    Sir, I have a voluntary welfare home in my constituency known as the Geylang East Home for the Aged, which is presently managed by volunteers who are doing a great job. This home also operates a senior citizens'recreation centre and there are plans to provide more services, like day care centre for senior citizens. While the Ministry provides some support and assistance, I think the homes could certainly do with more advisory and administrative support from the Ministry of Community Development. May I suggest that perhaps the Ministry set up a secretariat which could help provide more services to voluntary welfare homes. Officers from the secretariat could visit the homes from time to time or attend their monthly management meetings to discuss issues and problems which their management committees face and to give advice and support wherever required.

    Sir, unlike the commercial homes for the aged, voluntary welfare homes depend on contribution from the public and they would have to watch their budgets carefully and therefore support and advice from experienced Ministry of Community Development officers would be very helpful.

    Sir, running a home for the aged is not an easy task. And volunteers who are prepared to do other community work are sometimes reluctant to serve in homes for the aged because of the onerous responsibility. Sir, in view of this, perhaps MCD could give more help to such homes and in this way I think these homes could provide more services for our senior citizens.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, I am much obliged to you. I would like to speak on grants to child care services.

    There is no denying that there is a great demand for child care centres. A newspaper report in November last year had this as the headline: "Child care centres report full house and long queues". Owners of all private child care centres interviewed by the reporter who wrote the article said that they all had enrolment of maximum capacity. At some centres parents would have to wait up to six months to enrol their children. One centre reported that they had 143 people on their

Column: 744

waiting list and it was getting longer and longer. Another centre reported it had a capacity of 28 and it had a waiting list of about 100 since eight months earlier. Almost every private child care centre had the same story to tell.

    Why do parents want to send their infant children to child care centres? Some said that it was due to the subsidy given by the Government, others said that they do not want the child to be too attached to the maid, and there are others who said that they want their children to interact with other children and gain good social habits. But, Sir, above all, most parents do now realise that the child's learning capacity is at its greatest between the ages of 2 and 6 years old. Therefore, it is of paramount importance that a child of that age group be placed in the correct educational and social environment to reap the maximum benefit for the intellectual and social growth of the child.

    Despite the dire need for more child care centres, the MCD appears to be in no hurry to do something to meet the demand for more child care centres. I note that in the budget report that there are currently 11,666 children who are in child care centres. The MCD hopes to increase this number to 14,467 in FY 90. That number is only about 10-12% of the children who need to be enroled in child care centres. 85% of Singapore's population reside in HDB flats and most of the parents are working parents. I estimate there must be at least 120,000 children in HDB estates who need places in child care centres. Therefore, I would urge the MCD to look more seriously into the building of more child care centres at HDB housing estates. The task is most urgent if the Government wants to get mothers to go into the labour market.

    I note that the Government is to build six more child care centres in new HDB estates. I say that this is definitely not enough. Even if the Government builds 60 more new centres they would not be enough. The task ahead in regard to providing child care centres is not only urgently needed but a gigantic one.

    The $14 million allocated for subsidy to child care centres is a paltry one. I think

Column: 745

this figure needs to be increased drastically, especially there will be a shortage of good teachers to teach in these child care centres.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Dr Seet Ai Mee): Sir, Mr Chiam See Tong on Wednesday stated that there was no welfare programme in Singapore and that the Government does not support welfare. Fortunately his statement is untrue. Otherwise the Welfare Services Programme which constitutes a major section of the Ministry of Community Development would be non-existent, and we as the House would not today be debating the Welfare Services budget.

    Sir, hon. Members have dwelt on a wide range of topics, from destitute and low income families, to family service centres, before and after school care programmes, child care centres and programmes for senior citizens.

    Sir, the family is the basic building block of our society, as Mrs Yu-Foo has reminded this House very aptly. We must promote programmes and services to preserve the family unit and buttress the family to weather crises. When our families are strong, our nation will be strong. We need to ensure the retention of suitable core values which promote diligence, sense of responsibility for the family and the nation, and love and respect for elders.      The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Sir, allow me in the limited time left to respond to the Member for Pasir Panjang GRC, Mr Bernard Chen, who touched on the supply and demand of hotel rooms in Singapore, which was also a subject which Dr Wang Kai Yuen touched on.

    First of all, they are correct in saying that there is now a shortage of hotel rooms. The average hotel occupancy rate for 1989 was 87%. For this year, as they have pointed out, it is even higher. This is a cyclical business. After several years of glut, there is now a shortage of rooms and the hotels are facing a boom. As a result of this, the average hotel room price, in other words, the weighted average of all gazetted hotel rooms in Singapore, from expensive to moderate to the cheaper hotels, was $115 in 1985. It has risen to $164 currently. But just to put things in perspective, let me point out that even at this price we are among the cheapest in the region, especially when compared to our main competitors, Hong Kong and Bangkok.

    Looking down the road, STPB projects that the hotel room shortage will get worse, especially, as Dr Wang pointed out, after 1995. The URA has been releasing prime land for commercial development which can be used for either retail, office or hotel. But at the current average room price which I quoted just now, $164 a room night, hotel development cannot compete with retail and with office development. Average bids for hotel uses currently run at slightly less than 50%. In fact, it is about 43% of that for office and retail uses. So very clearly, left on its own, this trend is expected to continue and developers will choose to build offices and shopping centres rather than hotels until the price of the rooms is high enough for hotel developments to be viable.

    Mr Bernard Chen's point that the tourism sector is important to the economy is well taken. The Government has decided that it will release some land specifically for hotel development. For a start, the Government will release land which can cater to about 50% of the projected hotel rooms which are required.
